prompt: evidence is lots. ->
completion:
The ground in the northern part of the site was very stony and offered no

potential for bat activity. The southern end of this area had a small amount

of standing water which could conceivably provide some habitat if it were deep enough, but there is no evidence that bats have ever used this space. A number of individual bat droppings were found here as well as on top of the walls around these areas. In summary, despite extensive searching throughout all aspects of the building and its immediate surroundings (including inside all cupboards/storage spaces), no signs at all indicative of current or historic bat use (e.g., discarded prey items) were located anywhere within or immediately adjacent to any aspect(s) covered by this survey; clearly demonstrating that bats are not currently using any aspect(s) covered by this survey for roosting purposes).

prompt: conclusion. potential is high. wall_condition is bad. roof_condition is bad. ->
completion: The building had a number of potential bat access points. The walls were generally intact although there were some gaps and missing mortar in the pointing. There was clear evidence of bats having previously roosted inside the roof due to droppings being present, however no current activity could be seen or heard here. It was concluded that this site did have some Potential Roost Features and it is considered suitable for bats based on these factors. In summary, all buildings had various levels of suitability for bats with numerous potential roost features throughout (e.g., cracks in internal walls). A thorough search around the exterior found no evidence of any possible bat activity such as discarded prey items or droppings; therefore it was concluded that no significant bat use areas existed within close proximity to this site." To summarise, despite an extensive survey around the entire building complex not one single piece of dropped material nor even a footprint could be identified anywhere which clearly showed zero possibility for bats to enter via those routes so overall conclusion is negligible PRFs across all aspects examined = No Significant Potential Roost Features (NSPS) present at all! This clearly shows that there are many opportunities for small mammals such as rats and mice to get into loft space through holes in ridge tiles etc
